DOC.HEAD: Official Says Westinghouse May Appeal Bonus Payment
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. is considering appealing for an increase in the $3.9 million bonus it won for running the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant despite safety lapses such as workers sleeping on the job, an Energy Department official said Friday. Westinghouse officials at the South Carolina plant, however, said there were no plans to appeal. Stephen A. Wakefield, the department's general counsel, said Westinghouse President Paul E. Lego told Energy Secretary James D. Watkins in a meeting earlier this week that the company was considering contesting the amount of the award. ``I know they're considering it,'' Wakefield said in an interview in his office, adding that Lego gave no indication that a firm decision had been made. At the Savannah River plant, near Aiken, S.C., Westinghouse spokesman Jack Herman said James Moore, president of the Westinghouse subsidiary that operates the facility, told him Friday, ``There's no intention to appeal.'' ``We view this as a fait accompli,'' Herman said in reference to the department's decision announced earlier this week to give the company $3.9 million out of a maximum possible award fee of $7.5 million for its first six months as operator. Wakefield said Westinghouse was unhappy that it had been docked so heavily for not meeting the Energy Department's expectations for improving the plant's performance. Westinghouse, which runs all or parts of five other Energy Department weapons plants, took over from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. at Savannah River last April amid rising public criticism of environmental, health and safety problems in the weapons complex. Savannah River's three nuclear reactors, which are the nation's only source of tritium needed to make nuclear warheads, have been closed down for more than a year for safety reasons. Westinghouse has been conducting a massive overhaul of the plant in preparation for restarting the reactors next year. In a letter Dec. 13, P.W. Kaspar, DOE's manager of the Savannah River operations office, told Moore that although Westinghouse had made some important improvements, its overall approach to instilling more discipline in plant operations was too narrow and not yet effective. Kaspar said the company had not adequately reacted to ``anomalies throughout the site.'' Among the anomalies cited were employees found asleep when they were supposed to have been monitoring the testing of cooling pipes at one of the reactors. Westinghouse said unspecified disciplinary action was taken against the two workers found asleep. They were not fired. Another problem cited by Kaspar was that Westinghouse employees had intentionally disabled alarms meant to detect excessive radiation. The company said two employees recently were fired for tampering with alarms, one in a reactor area. Wakefield said Westinghouse's displeasure with the amount of its bonus payment did not indicate that the contract relationship was deteriorating. He said Savannah River operations had improved greatly since Westinghouse took over last April, and that no one was aware then of how bad the problems there were. ``Westinghouse found a much more difficult situation there than they expected or than we expected,'' said Wakefield. ``Du Pont had really let the place run down.''
